week1.title: Week 1: Introduction to Physics of Motion
week1.description: Test your understanding of fundamental motion concepts in baseball physics

questions.question: What is the difference between distance and displacement?
options: Distance is a vector, displacement is a scalar
Distance is always greater than displacement
Distance is total path length, displacement is straight-line change in position
questions.explanation: Distance measures the total path traveled (scalar), while displacement measures the straight-line change in position (vector).

commonMistakes.0: Remember that vectors have direction, scalars don't. Distance is the scalar, displacement is the vector.
commonMistakes.1: While this is often true, it's not the fundamental difference between the concepts.
commonMistakes.3: These are distinctly different concepts - one describes total path, the other describes net change in position.

hints: Think about running around a track vs. your final position
Consider which quantity cares about direction and which doesn't

questions.question: A pitcher throws a ball with initial velocity 30 m/s at 25° above horizontal. What is the horizontal component of velocity?
questions.formula: vₓ = v₀ cos(θ), vᵧ = v₀ sin(θ)
questions.explanation: The horizontal component is v₀ cos(θ) = 30 cos(25°) ≈ 27.2 m/s

commonMistakes.1: This would be the vertical component using sine, not the horizontal component.
commonMistakes.2: Tangent is not used for vector components; use cosine for horizontal, sine for vertical.
commonMistakes.3: This is the total velocity magnitude, not just the horizontal component.

hints: Remember: cosine for horizontal (adjacent), sine for vertical (opposite)
Draw a right triangle with the velocity vector as the hypotenuse

questions.question: Explain why velocity and speed are different physical quantities.
questions.sampleAnswer: Velocity is a vector quantity that includes both magnitude and direction, while speed is a scalar quantity that only describes magnitude. A baseball traveling in a circle at constant speed has changing velocity due to direction changes.
hints: Think about what information each quantity provides
Consider a car driving around a circular track at constant speed
One quantity tells you 'how fast', the other tells you 'how fast and which way'

week2.title: Week 2: Understanding Projectile Motion
week2.description: Test your understanding of projectile motion principles in baseball

questions.question: At what angle should a baseball be thrown to achieve maximum range (ignoring air resistance)?
questions.explanation: For projectile motion without air resistance, maximum range occurs at 45° launch angle.

commonMistakes.0: 30° would give less than maximum range - the optimal angle is higher.
commonMistakes.2: 60° is too steep - you'd get good height but not maximum distance.
commonMistakes.3: 90° would make the ball go straight up and land at the same spot!

hints: Think about the trade-off between height and horizontal distance
The range equation involves sin(2θ), which is maximum when 2θ = 90°

questions.question: A baseball is hit with initial velocity 35 m/s at 30° above horizontal. Calculate the maximum height reached.
Which component of projectile motion is affected by gravity?
questions.explanation: Gravity only affects the vertical component of motion. Horizontal velocity remains constant (ignoring air resistance).

week3.title: Week 3: Forces and Newton's Laws of Motion
week3.description: Test your understanding of forces and Newton's laws in baseball

questions.question: According to Newton's First Law, a baseball in flight will continue in motion unless acted upon by:
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law states that an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced (net) force.

questions.question: A 0.145 kg baseball experiences a net force of 15 N. Calculate its acceleration.
Explain how Newton's Third Law applies when a pitcher throws a baseball.
questions.sampleAnswer: When the pitcher applies a force to the baseball (action), the baseball applies an equal and opposite force back on the pitcher's hand (reaction). The pitcher experiences a backwards force equal in magnitude to the forward force applied to the ball.

week4.title: Week 4: Momentum and Impulse
week4.description: Test your understanding of momentum and impulse in baseball collisions

questions.question: What is the momentum of a 0.145 kg baseball traveling at 40 m/s?
questions.explanation: Momentum p = mv = 0.145 kg × 40 m/s = 5.8 kg⋅m/s

questions.question: A baseball bat applies an average force of 5000 N for 0.002 seconds. Calculate the impulse delivered to the ball.

solution.step2: Impulse = F × Δt = 5000 N × 0.002 s = 10 N⋅s

week5.title: Week 5: Work and Energy in Baseball Pitching
week5.description: Test your understanding of work, energy, and power in baseball pitching mechanics

questions.question: Which type of energy does a baseball have at the top of its trajectory?
questions.explanation: At the top of its trajectory, the ball has potential energy due to its height and kinetic energy due to its horizontal motion.

commonMistakes.0: Remember that vertical velocity is zero at the top, but horizontal velocity continues.
commonMistakes.1: The ball still has horizontal motion at the top of trajectory, giving it kinetic energy.
commonMistakes.3: The ball has both height (potential energy) and motion (kinetic energy).

hints: Think about what happens to horizontal and vertical velocity components separately
Energy is conserved - what forms can it take?

questions.question: Calculate the kinetic energy of a 0.145 kg baseball traveling at 30 m/s.
hints: Remember that velocity is squared in the kinetic energy formula
Don't forget the ½ factor in the kinetic energy equation

questions.question: Explain how the work-energy theorem applies to a pitcher accelerating a baseball.
questions.sampleAnswer: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy. A pitcher applies force through a distance during the acceleration phase, doing positive work on the ball. This work directly converts to the ball's kinetic energy, increasing its speed from zero to the final velocity at release.
hints: Consider what happens when force is applied through a distance
Think about how the ball's motion changes during the pitch

week6.title: Week 6: Circular Motion and Angular Velocity
week6.description: Test your understanding of rotational motion and angular mechanics in pitching

questions.question: What provides the centripetal force for a curveball's spinning motion?
questions.explanation: Air pressure differences created by the ball's spin (Magnus effect) provide the centripetal force that curves the ball's path.

commonMistakes.0: Gravity acts downward, not toward the center of the curved path.
commonMistakes.2: The pitcher's hand only contacts the ball during release, not throughout flight.
commonMistakes.3: Friction affects spin but doesn't provide the centripetal force for the curved path.

hints: Think about what causes the ball to curve after it leaves the pitcher's hand
Consider the Magnus effect and pressure differences

questions.question: A baseball spins at 2400 rpm. Convert this to radians per second.

week7.title: Week 7: Torque and Angular Momentum
week7.description: Test your understanding of rotational forces and angular momentum in baseball

questions.question: Which factor does NOT affect the torque applied by a pitcher's arm?
questions.explanation: Torque = r × F × sin(θ). The mass of the baseball doesn't directly affect the torque applied by the pitcher's arm.

questions.question: Explain how conservation of angular momentum applies to a pitcher's delivery.
questions.sampleAnswer: During the pitching motion, as the pitcher brings their arm closer to their body (decreasing the moment of inertia), their angular velocity increases to conserve angular momentum. This helps generate higher ball speeds.

week8.title: Week 8: The Physics of Spin
week8.description: Test your understanding of spin effects and the Magnus force in baseball flight

questions.question: The Magnus effect causes a spinning baseball to:
questions.explanation: The Magnus effect causes the ball to experience a force perpendicular to both its velocity and spin axis, changing its direction.

questions.question: Which type of spin causes a baseball to drop more rapidly than expected?
questions.explanation: Topspin creates a Magnus force that acts downward, causing the ball to drop more rapidly than a ball without spin.

questions.question: Air resistance on a baseball depends on which factors?
questions.explanation: Drag force depends on velocity squared, cross-sectional area, air density, and drag coefficient.

questions.question: Calculate the drag force on a baseball (drag coefficient = 0.3, area = 0.0042 m², air density = 1.225 kg/m³) traveling at 40 m/s.

solution.step1: Given: Cd = 0.3, A = 0.0042 m², ρ = 1.225 kg/m³, v = 40 m/s

questions.question: The kinetic chain in pitching refers to:
options: The sequential activation of body segments
The connection between pitcher and catcher
questions.explanation: The kinetic chain describes how energy transfers sequentially from the legs through the core, shoulder, arm, and finally to the ball.

questions.question: How does the length of a pitcher's stride affect ball velocity and accuracy?
questions.sampleAnswer: A longer stride can increase ball velocity by allowing more time for acceleration and energy transfer through the kinetic chain. However, an overly long stride can reduce accuracy by making timing more difficult and reducing control over release point.

questions.question: Which measurement tool would be most accurate for measuring baseball velocity?
questions.explanation: Radar guns are specifically designed for accurate velocity measurements and are the standard tool used in professional baseball.

questions.question: Five measurements of baseball velocity were: 42, 44, 43, 45, 41 m/s. Calculate the mean and standard deviation.

week12.title: Week 12: The Physics of Pitching Equipment

questions.question: How does the height of the pitching mound affect ball trajectory?
questions.explanation: The elevated mound (10 inches high) creates a steeper downward angle, making it more difficult for batters to make solid contact.

questions.question: Explain how the construction and materials of a baseball affect its flight characteristics.
questions.sampleAnswer: The baseball's cork center provides bounce, the rubber and yarn windings control weight distribution and elasticity, and the leather covering with raised seams creates air turbulence that affects drag and allows spin to be more effective through the Magnus effect.

questions.question: Which physics principle is MOST important for understanding why a curveball curves?
questions.explanation: The Magnus effect, caused by the interaction between the ball's spin and air flow, is the primary reason curveballs and other breaking balls change direction.

questions.question: A comprehensive problem: A baseball is thrown at 35 m/s at 25° above horizontal from 2m height. Calculate: a) time to reach maximum height, b) maximum height reached, c) total flight time.

solution.step2: a) Time to max height: t = v₀ᵧ/g = 14.8/9.81 = 1.51 s
solution.step4: c) Total flight time found by solving: -2 = 14.8t - 4.905t²

questions.question: Synthesize your understanding: How do ALL the physics principles studied this semester work together in a single pitch?
questions.sampleAnswer: A single pitch involves: kinematics (projectile motion), dynamics (forces and torques in the delivery), energy transfer (kinetic chain), momentum and impulse (ball-bat collision), rotational motion (spin), fluid dynamics (air resistance and Magnus effect), and optimization principles (biomechanics). All these work together to determine the ball's trajectory, speed, movement, and ultimate success.
